question_details.title: Will Australia recognize Palestine before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-26 09:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38939). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The Australian government has [historically supported](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Palestine_relations) a two-state solution but has stopped short of formal recognition. In 2025, a growing number of Australian lawmakers, particularly within the Labor Party, have recently urged the federal government to officially recognize a Palestinian state. According to [the Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2025/jul/25/australia-news-live-marles-wong-aukus-trade-beef-submarines-productivity-summit-albanese-chalmers-ley-ntwnfb):

> Former minister and Labor backbencher, **Ed Husic**, has said France’s announcement to recognise Palestinian statehood was the “perfect opportunity” for Australia to follow suit.
> ‎
> He told ABC’s Afternoon Briefing: "This is a fairly comprehensive statement that France has put out, and I think it is one that Australia has the perfect opportunity now to stand with the French to recognise the state of Palestine."
> ‎
> He said the Labor party at its two most recent national conferences had reaffirmed recognising the state of Palestine, and the “brutality over the last 20 months” had led many nations to rethink their approach to this issue.

This comes amid a broader international movement supporting Palestinian statehood, including formal recognition by countries such as [Spain, Ireland, and Norway](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/28/ireland-norway-and-spain-recognised-palestine-what-has-that-changed) in 2024.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":38939,"question_id":38279}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, the Australian federal government officially announces that it is formally recognizing the State of Palestine, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

Here are the relevant news articles:

**SBS News in Easy English 8 October 2025**
Australia and Singapore have strengthened their bilateral ties by launching an updated Comprehensive Strategic Partnership during a meeting in Canberra between Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, ten years after the original agreement. The new partnership focuses on defence, economic stability, climate change, pandemic preparedness, and emerging technology research. Meanwhile, seven Australians detained in Israel for attempting to deliver aid to Gaza have criticized the Australian government for a lack of support, with Juliet Lamont stating they were not assisted with their deportation to Jordan and claiming they were physically abused and denied food and water during detention; Israel denies mistreatment, while DFAT confirms it continues consular assistance. A total of 472 out of 479 people detained in the flotilla incident have now been deported. In Australia, Optus failed to notify the Department of Communications of a major triple-zero outage on September 18, 2025, due to an email sent to the wrong address, and the government was not informed until September 19, more than 24 hours later; the outage affected 600 emergency calls. The Tasmanian government argues that not building the proposed $1 billion AFL stadium on the Hobart waterfront would cause reputational damage and harm future generations, despite the planning commission’s formal recommendation against it; the government maintains the stadium would bring unquantifiable benefits like community pride and job creation, and although opposition Labor supports it, passage of legislation in the upper house remains uncertain. The European Union has urged Afghanistan’s Taliban government to improve women’s rights, as it announces over $350 million in humanitarian aid, emphasizing that aid delivery depends on lifting restrictions on women, especially after a recent earthquake. In sports, Arsenal’s women’s team, featuring three Matildas, began their defence of the Women’s European Champions League title with a 2-1 loss to French side Lyon, the eight-time champions.

**The Two-State Solution: A Pivotal Moment**
A high-level conference on achieving a peaceful resolution to the Palestinian issue and implementing the two-state solution is taking place in New York on Monday, October 7, 2025, alongside the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly. This follows the launch of the 'International Coalition for the Implementation of the Two-State Solution' during the previous session, which included Arab, Islamic, European, and international organizations such as the Arab League, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, and the European Union. Egypt hosted the coalition’s fourth conference in February 2025, following earlier meetings in Saudi Arabia, Belgium, and Norway. At the prior New York conference in July 2025, Egypt called on the international community to build on its outcomes to advance comprehensive and fair peace, emphasizing that there is no alternative to fulfilling the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people, including liberation from occupation and the establishment of a contiguous, viable, independent Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital. Egypt also urged support for the Arab-Islamic recovery and reconstruction plan for Gaza, and the cessation of systematic Israeli violations in the West Bank. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi discussed the importance of the conference in a phone call with French President Emmanuel Macron, stressing its role as a pivotal step toward recognizing Palestine and implementing the two-state solution based on pre-1967 borders. Sisi welcomed France’s announced intent to recognize Palestine, calling it a positive contribution to achieving a just and comprehensive Middle East peace, and urged other non-recognizing states to follow suit. Egypt reiterated its unwavering support for Palestine as the central issue of the Arab nation, emphasizing that regional stability cannot be achieved without a fair and comprehensive resolution to the Palestinian conflict. This stance was reaffirmed during the emergency Arab-Islamic summit in Doha, where Sisi underscored that no state’s sovereignty would be violated and peace efforts would not be undermined, with all Arab and Islamic nations standing united in defense of Palestinian rights. Egypt co-founded the International Coalition, with Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty stating that the current crisis stems not from October 7, 2023, but from years of illegal Israeli occupation, land confiscation, and demographic engineering, necessitating the fulfillment of Palestinian aspirations for independence. The conference is seen as a pivotal moment, especially after the UN General Assembly adopted the 'New York Declaration'—the closing statement from the previous conference—containing a 'roadmap' for lasting, fair, and comprehensive peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Additionally, the UK, Australia, Canada, and Portugal recognized Palestine on Sunday, October 6, 2025, with at least ten more countries, including France, expected to follow shortly, despite Israel’s ongoing military offensive to seize control of Gaza, the largest urban center in the territory.

**International Outcry Grows Over Israel’s Gaza War: Europe and Latin America Escalate Pressure Amid Calls for Accountability**
On the second anniversary of the Gaza war, international condemnation of Israel intensified, with Europe and Latin America adopting stronger stances. Spain led European diplomatic efforts by formally recognizing Palestine in May 2024, imposing a comprehensive arms export ban to Israel, and blocking military cargo from entering Spanish ports. Spanish Foreign Minister José Manuel Albares demanded an immediate and unconditional halt to Israeli military operations in Gaza, stating, 'This war must stop now, regardless of negotiations,' and affirmed Spain’s support for a viable, independent Palestinian state. Spain also called for revising EU-Israel partnership agreements based on human rights, a move described as a 'painful diplomatic blow' to Israel. Ireland and Norway suspended military cooperation, while Belgium joined calls to freeze the EU-Israel partnership, citing ethical and legal violations. France saw rising public and parliamentary pressure to halt arms sales and launch an international investigation into civilian casualties. The UK witnessed large-scale protests demanding a ban on companies supplying arms to Israel. The Netherlands blocked entry to extremist Israeli officials and supported EU-imposed economic restrictions, particularly on goods from Israeli settlements. Italy, under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, called for a ceasefire, demanded humanitarian access to Gaza, and expressed readiness to recognize Palestine—conditional on the release of all Israeli hostages and the exclusion of Hamas from any future Palestinian government. Italy joined a joint statement by 25 countries calling for an immediate end to hostilities and humanitarian access. The EU issued a statement in September 2024 calling for an immediate ceasefire, condemning the Gaza blockade as an 'unacceptable collective punishment,' reaffirming support for a two-state solution, and endorsing ICC investigations into alleged war crimes. In Latin America, Colombia severed all diplomatic ties with Israel in May 2024, calling it a 'racist apartheid state committing crimes against humanity.' Bolivia and Chile recalled ambassadors in protest, while Brazil froze all arms deals with Israel and reassessed military and intelligence cooperation. Argentina, Nicaragua, and Peru supported UN-led investigations and signed a joint resolution demanding an independent international mission to document violations. CELAC reaffirmed full support for Palestinian rights and called for sanctions against Israeli officials responsible for attacks on civilians. According to Spanish newspaper La Razón, public opinion in Spain, Germany, and France shows over 60% of citizens demanding reduced cooperation with Israel, and the number of countries recognizing Palestine has risen to over 150, including three new European states in 2024. Analysts view this as the beginning of a growing diplomatic isolation of Israel, fueled by pressure from human rights groups and the ICC, which has opened investigations into attacks on hospitals, schools, and shelters in Gaza. The second anniversary marked not only a remembrance of the tragedy but also a turning point in global policy, with increasing calls for justice, accountability, and an end to the 18-year-long blockade of Gaza.

**View from The Hill: Two years of a distant war have brought much damage to Australian society**
Two years after the Hamas attacks in Israel on October 7, 2023, Australia has experienced significant societal damage due to the ongoing Middle East conflict. Pro-Palestinian demonstrations, including graffiti such as 'Glory to Hamas' and 'Oct 7, do it again' in Melbourne’s Fitzroy, have been labeled 'terrorist propaganda' by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who called for legal consequences. A court case is ongoing over whether a protest outside the Sydney Opera House should be permitted, with the Palestine Action Group (PAG) arguing that denying the protest would set a dangerous precedent for free expression in Australia, framing the issue as constitutional. The conflict has deeply fractured Australian social cohesion, raised tensions around multiculturalism, and intensified debates over free speech, protest rights, and hate speech laws. NSW Premier Chris Minns acknowledged the balancing act between free expression and protection from vilification, noting that recent changes to hate speech laws are currently under challenge in the High Court. The Australian Jewish community has faced increased fear and attacks, including two incidents linked to Iran, which sought to incite division. Palestinian supporters have maintained consistent weekend demonstrations. The Australia-Israel relationship has deteriorated, with the Albanese government criticizing Israel’s military actions and recognizing Palestinian statehood at the UN—policies that have drawn sharp criticism from the Coalition, which accuses Labor of abandoning a key ally. The Greens have taken a progressive stance on Palestine, while public opinion remains divided: a September 2024 Essential poll showed 34% support and 30% opposition to Palestinian state recognition. The once-bipartisan Middle East policy, which long supported Israel and a two-state solution, has collapsed, with the Coalition now strongly pro-Israel and accusing Labor of failing to combat antisemitism. These divisions, which existed before October 7, 2023, have widened dramatically. Even if peace emerges, lasting fractures, anger, and fear are expected to persist, leaving governments with enduring policy challenges.

**Rising International Recognition Revives the Two-State Solution Efforts**
As of October 6, 2025, 159 out of 193 United Nations member states have recognized Palestine, following a wave of international recognition that has intensified after two years of war in Gaza. In recent days, 11 countries—Britain, Canada, Australia, Portugal, Luxembourg, Belgium, Andorra, France, Malta, Monaco, and San Marino—joined the list, raising the total. Although these recognitions may not immediately alter the on-the-ground situation, they mark a significant breach in the long-standing international silence favoring Israel. The growing global awareness of the Gaza humanitarian crisis and increasing domestic pressure from voters, human rights organizations, and academic institutions have driven this shift. The French and British recognitions are particularly historic: France’s move breaks from its prior stance requiring peace negotiations, while Britain’s shift signals a major policy change, reflecting a broader evolving political mood in Europe. The recognition trend undermines Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s strategy to derail the two-state solution and prevent regional stability. These developments strengthen the global push to end the Israeli occupation and reinforce the two-state solution as the only viable path to peace. Despite the United States’ continued alignment with Israel, the momentum of international recognition challenges the era of unconditional Western support for Israel and underscores growing global consensus on Palestinian rights.

**Jordanian Royal Couple Received at Élysée by Macron, Discussing Regional Stability and Palestine Recognition**
On Wednesday, October 8, 2025, the French President Emmanuel Macron and First Lady Brigitte Macron hosted the Jordanian royal couple, Prince Hussein bin Abdullah and Princess Rajwa Al Hussein, at the Élysée Palace for their first official state visit to France. According to a statement from the Élysée, the meeting aimed to reaffirm the 'friendship and trust' between France and Jordan and to strengthen bilateral cooperation in economic, technological, security, and defense sectors. Prince Hussein, 31, is the heir to the Jordanian throne and son of King Abdullah II and Queen Rania; he married Rajwa Al Saïf in June 2023. Their first child, Princess Iman bint al-Hussein, was born in August 2024. The discussion included Jordan’s 'essential role in regional stability,' particularly regarding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. On September 23, 2025, King Abdullah condemned 'an illegal occupation and flagrant violations of numerous UN resolutions, international law, and human rights conventions' at the United Nations. The day before, President Macron announced France’s recognition of Palestine, a move also adopted by Canada, Australia, Norway, the UK, Spain, Belgium, and Ireland.

**UK, Canada, and Australia Announce Recognition of Palestinian State Amid International and Israeli Reactions**
On September 21, 2025, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia jointly announced the recognition of the State of Palestine, stating this action was part of a coordinated international effort. The three nations emphasized that the terrorist organization Hamas must not survive or participate in future democratic elections in Palestine, called for a ceasefire in Gaza, and demanded the release of hostages. They cited direct commitments from the Palestinian Authority to reform and hold democratic elections excluding Hamas. This announcement followed their prior pledge in July 2025 to recognize Palestine before the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly, which began on September 9, 2025, with its high-level week running from September 22 to September 30. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu responded by condemning the move as a threat to Israel’s survival, accusing the three nations of rewarding terrorism and warning of future Israeli retaliation. He reiterated Israel’s stance of achieving peace through strength, stating, 'I have to tell you: this will not happen. A Palestinian state will not be established west of the Jordan River.' **The Two-State Solution: A Pivotal Moment**
A high-level conference on achieving a peaceful resolution to the Palestinian issue and implementing the two-state solution is taking place in New York on Monday, October 7, 2025, alongside the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly. This follows the launch of the 'International Coalition for the Implementation of the Two-State Solution' during the previous session, which included Arab, Islamic, European, and international organizations such as the Arab League, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, and the European Union. Egypt hosted the coalition’s fourth conference in February 2025, following earlier meetings in Saudi Arabia, Belgium, and Norway. At the prior New York conference in July 2025, Egypt called on the international community to build on its outcomes to advance comprehensive and fair peace, emphasizing that there is no alternative to fulfilling the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people, including liberation from occupation and the establishment of a contiguous, viable, independent Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital. Egypt also urged support for the Arab-Islamic recovery and reconstruction plan for Gaza, and the cessation of systematic Israeli violations in the West Bank. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi discussed the importance of the conference in a phone call with French President Emmanuel Macron, stressing its role as a pivotal step toward recognizing Palestine and implementing the two-state solution based on pre-1967 borders. Sisi welcomed France’s announced intent to recognize Palestine, calling it a positive contribution to achieving a just and comprehensive Middle East peace, and urged other non-recognizing states to follow suit. Egypt reiterated its unwavering support for Palestine as the central issue of the Arab nation, emphasizing that regional stability cannot be achieved without a fair and comprehensive resolution to the Palestinian conflict. This stance was reaffirmed during the emergency Arab-Islamic summit in Doha, where Sisi underscored that no state’s sovereignty would be violated and peace efforts would not be undermined, with all Arab and Islamic nations standing united in defense of Palestinian rights. Egypt co-founded the International Coalition, with Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty stating that the current crisis stems not from October 7, 2023, but from years of illegal Israeli occupation, land confiscation, and demographic engineering, necessitating the fulfillment of Palestinian aspirations for independence. The conference is seen as a pivotal moment, especially after the UN General Assembly adopted the 'New York Declaration'—the closing statement from the previous conference—containing a 'roadmap' for lasting, fair, and comprehensive peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Additionally, the UK, Australia, Canada, and Portugal recognized Palestine on Sunday, October 6, 2025, with at least ten more countries, including France, expected to follow shortly, despite Israel’s ongoing military offensive to seize control of Gaza, the largest urban center in the territory.

**Reading council to welcomes recognition of Palestinian statehood by government**
Reading Borough Council is set to welcome the UK government's recognition of Palestine as an independent state, announced on September 21, 2024. The motion, introduced by Labour councillor Liz Terry (Coley), acknowledges the State of Palestine as comprising the West Bank and Gaza Strip, territories separated by Israel. The motion expresses support for the UK government’s commitment to a two-state solution, condemns the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack that killed 1,195 people, wounded 3,400, and resulted in 251 captives, and calls for the immediate release of all hostages. It also affirms the UK’s moral and legal responsibility to uphold international humanitarian law and prevent further civilian suffering in Gaza. The motion supports an immediate ceasefire, the safe return of hostages, and a two-state solution, urging all parties to end the humanitarian crisis in Gaza. Council members are asked to consent to Terry writing a letter to Foreign Secretary David Lammy in support of the recognition. The motion will be debated at a full council meeting on October 14, 2025, marking the second anniversary of the Hamas invasion. The 'two-state solution' concept originated from UN Resolution 181 (1947), which failed to establish separate states after the British Mandate ended in 1948; Israel was declared in May 1948, followed by the 1967 Six-Day War, which expanded Israeli control into Palestinian territories.

**International Outcry Grows Over Israel’s Gaza War: Europe and Latin America Escalate Pressure Amid Calls for Accountability**
On the second anniversary of the Gaza war, international condemnation of Israel intensified, with Europe and Latin America adopting stronger stances. Spain led European diplomatic efforts by formally recognizing Palestine in May 2024, imposing a comprehensive arms export ban to Israel, and blocking military cargo from entering Spanish ports. Spanish Foreign Minister José Manuel Albares demanded an immediate and unconditional halt to Israeli military operations in Gaza, stating, 'This war must stop now, regardless of negotiations,' and affirmed Spain’s support for a viable, independent Palestinian state. Spain also called for revising EU-Israel partnership agreements based on human rights, a move described as a 'painful diplomatic blow' to Israel. Ireland and Norway suspended military cooperation, while Belgium joined calls to freeze the EU-Israel partnership, citing ethical and legal violations. France saw rising public and parliamentary pressure to halt arms sales and launch an international investigation into civilian casualties. The UK witnessed large-scale protests demanding a ban on companies supplying arms to Israel. The Netherlands blocked entry to extremist Israeli officials and supported EU-imposed economic restrictions, particularly on goods from Israeli settlements. Italy, under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, called for a ceasefire, demanded humanitarian access to Gaza, and expressed readiness to recognize Palestine—conditional on the release of all Israeli hostages and the exclusion of Hamas from any future Palestinian government. Italy joined a joint statement by 25 countries calling for an immediate end to hostilities and humanitarian access. The EU issued a statement in September 2024 calling for an immediate ceasefire, condemning the Gaza blockade as an 'unacceptable collective punishment,' reaffirming support for a two-state solution, and endorsing ICC investigations into alleged war crimes. In Latin America, Colombia severed all diplomatic ties with Israel in May 2024, calling it a 'racist apartheid state committing crimes against humanity.' Bolivia and Chile recalled ambassadors in protest, while Brazil froze all arms deals with Israel and reassessed military and intelligence cooperation. Argentina, Nicaragua, and Peru supported UN-led investigations and signed a joint resolution demanding an independent international mission to document violations. CELAC reaffirmed full support for Palestinian rights and called for sanctions against Israeli officials responsible for attacks on civilians. According to Spanish newspaper La Razón, public opinion in Spain, Germany, and France shows over 60% of citizens demanding reduced cooperation with Israel, and the number of countries recognizing Palestine has risen to over 150, including three new European states in 2024. Analysts view this as the beginning of a growing diplomatic isolation of Israel, fueled by pressure from human rights groups and the ICC, which has opened investigations into attacks on hospitals, schools, and shelters in Gaza. The second anniversary marked not only a remembrance of the tragedy but also a turning point in global policy, with increasing calls for justice, accountability, and an end to the 18-year-long blockade of Gaza.

**View from The Hill: Two years of a distant war have brought much damage to Australian society**
Two years after the Hamas attacks in Israel on October 7, 2023, Australia has experienced significant societal damage due to the ongoing Middle East conflict. Pro-Palestinian demonstrations, including graffiti such as 'Glory to Hamas' and 'Oct 7, do it again' in Melbourne’s Fitzroy, have been labeled 'terrorist propaganda' by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who called for legal consequences. A court case is ongoing over whether a protest outside the Sydney Opera House should be permitted, with the Palestine Action Group (PAG) arguing that denying the protest would set a dangerous precedent for free expression in Australia, framing the issue as constitutional. The conflict has deeply fractured Australian social cohesion, raised tensions around multiculturalism, and intensified debates over free speech, protest rights, and hate speech laws. NSW Premier Chris Minns acknowledged the balancing act between free expression and protection from vilification, noting that recent changes to hate speech laws are currently under challenge in the High Court. The Australian Jewish community has faced increased fear and attacks, including two incidents linked to Iran, which sought to incite division. Palestinian supporters have maintained consistent weekend demonstrations. The Australia-Israel relationship has deteriorated, with the Albanese government criticizing Israel’s military actions and recognizing Palestinian statehood at the UN—policies that have drawn sharp criticism from the Coalition, which accuses Labor of abandoning a key ally. The Greens have taken a progressive stance on Palestine, while public opinion remains divided: a September 2024 Essential poll showed 34% support and 30% opposition to Palestinian state recognition. The once-bipartisan Middle East policy, which long supported Israel and a two-state solution, has collapsed, with the Coalition now strongly pro-Israel and accusing Labor of failing to combat antisemitism. These divisions, which existed before October 7, 2023, have widened dramatically. Even if peace emerges, lasting fractures, anger, and fear are expected to persist, leaving governments with enduring policy challenges.

**Gaza War Opens Long-Awaited Battle for the Palestinian State**
Two years after October 7, 2023—the pivotal moment in the Palestinian-Israeli and Arab-Israeli conflict that reshaped the region—the central question remains unresolved: did the 'Al-Aqsa Flood' uprising bring the Palestinian state closer or destroy it permanently? While the war in Gaza has begun to subside, a new political battle has emerged over the establishment of a Palestinian state. Supporters argue that the attack prompted significant international recognition of Palestine, paving the way for statehood. Opponents counter that it was the Israeli military operations, mass casualties—including women and children—and unprecedented humanitarian crises that triggered global recognition, not the attack itself. As of October 2025, 158 out of 193 UN member states have recognized the State of Palestine, including major Western powers such as the UK, Canada, Australia, France, and Germany. This wave of recognition, particularly from key U.S. allies, has alarmed Israel, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declaring, 'No Palestinian state will be established, and we will respond to any attempt to impose a terrorist state on us in the heart of our country.' Israeli journalist Anat Barchaki described the recognition as a 'political earthquake' and a 'slow erosion of Israel’s diplomatic immunity,' signaling a changed international reality. The U.S. presidential plan by Donald Trump, while not guaranteeing statehood, opened a complex and contested path, with Palestinian sources emphasizing that recognition ignores the Palestinian Authority’s authority over Gaza. The Authority insists on leading post-war governance, including holding elections within a year, unifying security forces, combating corruption, reforming curricula, and ending payments to families of prisoners and martyrs. The Palestinian leadership has welcomed Trump’s efforts and issued a statement in the name of 'State of Palestine' for the first time, affirming commitment to the two-state solution and reforms. In contrast, Arab and Muslim foreign ministers issued a joint statement affirming support for the return of the Palestinian Authority to Gaza, unification of the West Bank and Gaza, a joint security mechanism, full Israeli withdrawal, reconstruction of Gaza, and a just peace based on two states. Netanyahu rejected any Palestinian governance in Gaza, stating that neither Hamas nor the Palestinian Authority would be involved in post-war administration. Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar declared, 'We will continue our struggle against the Palestinian state for years to come. I do not want to deceive the public—there is a real threat of a Palestinian state emerging.' The conflict has thus shifted from military to political, with global recognition now a key battleground between those supporting Palestinian statehood and Israel’s firm opposition.

**Rising International Recognition Revives the Two-State Solution Efforts**
As of October 6, 2025, 159 out of 193 United Nations member states have recognized Palestine, following a wave of international recognition that has intensified after two years of war in Gaza. In recent days, 11 countries—Britain, Canada, Australia, Portugal, Luxembourg, Belgium, Andorra, France, Malta, Monaco, and San Marino—joined the list, raising the total. Although these recognitions may not immediately alter the on-the-ground situation, they mark a significant breach in the long-standing international silence favoring Israel. The growing global awareness of the Gaza humanitarian crisis and increasing domestic pressure from voters, human rights organizations, and academic institutions have driven this shift. The French and British recognitions are particularly historic: France’s move breaks from its prior stance requiring peace negotiations, while Britain’s shift signals a major policy change, reflecting a broader evolving political mood in Europe. The recognition trend undermines Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s strategy to derail the two-state solution and prevent regional stability. These developments strengthen the global push to end the Israeli occupation and reinforce the two-state solution as the only viable path to peace. Despite the United States’ continued alignment with Israel, the momentum of international recognition challenges the era of unconditional Western support for Israel and underscores growing global consensus on Palestinian rights.

Australia joins 147 UN member states that have officially recognized Palestine since 2025, including regional powers such as China, Russia, South Africa, Brazil, and Indonesia. In Europe, countries like Sweden (2014), most Eastern European countries, and recently Spain, Norway, and Ireland (2024) have also recognized Palestine. French President Emmanuel Macron announced that France will also recognize Palestine and make a formal statement at the UN General Assembly in September, saying, 'In order to remain faithful to our historical commitment to a just and lasting peace in the Middle East, I have decided that France will recognize the Palestinian state.'
